WRITING.TITLE: What DC Rebirth Superman can teach Marvel and Captain America
WRITING.TEXT:
Before I began, let me preface this post by saying that the purpose of this post is not to start some kind of flame war in the comments, nor am I trying to belittle Marvel. Captain America is a character that means a lot to me personally and Rebirth Superman is my favorite thing going on in comics right now, and I think there's a lot Marvel can learn from what DC is doing right now, particularly with Superman, going forward.
Now with that being said...
I've always been a believer in the fact that every comics universe should have a sort of 'gold standard', someone that sets the example for what it means to be a hero in that particular universe. The character of Captain America has been among one of my biggest influences during not only during my teenage years, but also recently as I've become an adult and am making my way through college. Whenever I've had trouble figuring out the right thing in a situation or have trouble with adversity, I've always looked to Cap's example to help figure out a solution. Recently, however, I feel like Superman is beginning to take that slot.
With what's been going on leading up to and during Secret Empire, Marvel has essentially compromised their gold standard. And while yes, almost nothing in comics has that much of an impact and everything will probably go back to the way things were in a few months and,that a parallel can be drawn between what's happening with Cap and what DC did/is doing with Superman in the Injustice series, but DC didn't make the Superman in Injustice the Superman of the main continuity, unlike Marvel warping the fabric of the MU in order to justify the change with Cap.
With Rebirth, DC has managed to give readers fun, refreshing, interesting stories for Superman without changing the core of who he is. With Marvel Legacy, which is looking to become their answer to Rebirth, coming up in the fall, I hope Marvel learns that a character doesn't have to be fundamentally changed in order to have interesting stories.

That's a fair point and while I'm not the biggest fan of it, I will give Marvel credit for going as far as they are with Secret Empire and Hydra Cap. At some point though, you have to go back to Cap being the gold standard, and when they do, I hope Marvel looks to DC and Supes for influence.
The last part would have been amazing, especially with David Tennent or Matt Smith's Doctor. I could see just a handful of Time Lords wipe out the entirety of the Reapers.

You can have Steve go through adversity without having him do a complete 180 character wise.
And just out of curiosity, what about Rebirth is pandering or boring? Not trying to start anything, its just that I haven't heard anyone have that opinion about Rebirth.
I agree. The same can be said for Cyclopes as well. Bring back the first X-Man.
Who's to say that won't be the case in Legacy. Remember the basis of Supes current continuity started out as Lois and Clark.
Exactly, so why can't Marvel do it for Cap? I hope Marvel pays close attention to the success DC is having with Supes and applies the lessons learned to future Cap books.
I would have loved to have orbited Endor and found out that the Ewoks have held off the Reapers that same way they did the Empire in ROTJ.

I completely agree. As a matter of fact, I think Akksul and the Rokaer should have been the primary antagonists with the Kett being the Reaper level threat looming on the horizon. I think the Rokaer would have been a more sympathetic and complex group of enemies with motivations we can understand (defending your home from invaders from outer space is the basis for most modern science fiction)
